bioghist.p: The rare book dealer and writer Madeleine B. Stern was born July 1, 1912, in New York City, New York. She was educated at Barnard College (A.B., 1932) and Columbia University (M.A., 1934). In 1945 she began dealing rare books in a long-lasting partnership with Leona Rostenberg, and the two have collaborated on several memoirs that record their experiences in the book trade. Stern’s scholarly work includes several books and numerous articles on rare books, publishing history, women’s issues, nineteenth-century literature, and several biographies, including The Life of Margaret Fuller (1942) and Louisa May Alcott (1950). Stern is a member of many bibliographic and literary associations: Antiquarian Booksellers Association of America, Modern Language Association of America, American Printing History Association, Manuscript Society, Authors League of America, and the International League of Antiquarian Booksellers. She received a Guggenheim fellowship, 1943-45; the Medalie Award, Barnard College, 1982; and an American Printing History Association Award (with Leona Rostenberg), 1983. Nicholas Gouin Dufief (1776-1834), was a Franco-American bookseller and book-agent for Thomas Jefferson for whom he supplied many desiderata and with whom he carried on an extensive bibliophilic correspondence. Dufief also played a role in the dispersal of Benjamin Franklin's library and of the Westover (Virginia) library of William Byrd I and William Byrd II. The English Press of Paris, was operated by John Hurford Stone, a wealthy English coal merchant and an enthusiastic believer in the French Revolution.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of manuscripts and research materials related to Stern's articles on Nicholas Gouin Dufief published by the Philobiblon Club in 1988, and "The English Press in Paris and Its Successors," published in the Papers of the Bibliographic Society of America. Materials include: typescript manuscript drafts, galley proofs, photostats and photocopies of articles, books, and letters; handwritten notes; and a small amount of correspondence between Stern and librarians and other scholars.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
